channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Businessman draws attention to lease clause allowing rent cuts
item.description: A Taranaki business owner is warning leaseholders to read the fine print of their contracts after he was asked to pay his rent in full despite a clause in his lease allowing for a rent cut if he couldn't legally access the property.

item.title: Watch live: Epidemic Response Committee to discuss poverty and family violence
item.description: The Epidemic Response Committee will today hear from the Auckland City Mission and Women's Refuge.

item.title: Covid-19: Jobless immigrants face poverty, deportation, exploitation - immigration adviser
item.description: An immigration consultant is warning an entrenched underclass of unlawful workers will emerge unless the government provides emergency benefits to unemployed immigrants.

item.title: Live: Covid-19 updates from New Zealand and around the world on 30 April
item.description: School around the country are getting used to the new Covid-19 normal - juggling tiny classes with online teaching. Follow RNZ's blog for the latest.

item.title: Businesses breaking level 3 rules: 'Who you gonna call?'
item.description: Complaints of businesses breaching level 3 restrictions are flooding in, but there is uncertainty around who will police the breaches.

item.title: Man with terminal cancer loses 'precious days' in hospital wait
item.description: A cancer patient spent "precious days" in Palmerston North Hospital waiting for a procedure that should have taken an hour.

item.title: Auckland apartment searched in relation to Tongariro bones discovery
item.description: Police officers investigating the killing of a person found buried near Tongariro have searched a second Auckland property.

item.title: Fire at Auckland wreckers yard destroys cars
item.description: More than a dozen vehicles have been destroyed in a fire in the West Auckland suburb of New Lynn.

item.title: Long wait for construction of Northland's water storage facility
item.description: Drought-stricken Northland will have to wait until next summer for construction to begin on a water storage facility.

item.title: Covid-19: What happened in New Zealand on 29 April
item.description: Just two new cases of Covid-19 confirmed, Winston Peters' revealed the health ministry wanted closed borders, and the Epidemic Response Committee hears from medical practitioners.

item.title: New Zealand scientists working on various Covid-19 testing options
item.description: Supermarket workers and those in rest homes will likely be the target of new Covid-19 surveillance testing in level 3 to keep the virus under control.

item.title: Schools, ECEs reopen with fewer children than expected
item.description: Schools and ECEs reopened today for the first time in five weeks, but less than half the expected pupils attended.

item.title: Cycling popularity changes gear during lockdown and supporters look to capitalise
item.description: A survey has shown cycling was a popular new form of exercise during the lockdown, and people are now arguing for improved bike infrastructure.

item.title: Canterbury DHB to allow visitors under alert level 3
item.description: The Canterbury District Health Board has loosened restrictions on visitors to some of its facilities.

item.title: Fiordland tourism operators frustrated with national park rules
item.description: Fiordland tourism operators say the rules governing the national park are outdated and leave no room for common sense.

item.title: Sisters denied request to visit dying mother
item.description: Two sisters battling to get out of mandatory quarantine early to see their dying mother have had their appeal denied.

item.title: As it happened: Covid-19 updates from NZ and around the world
item.description: There were 742 complaints of businesses not complying with the rules on the first day of alert level 3. See how the rest of the day's events unfolded with RNZ's live blog.

item.title: Covid-19: A question about false negatives
item.description: Most of the audience questions we have answered during this Covid-19 madness have been straightforward, but sometimes one is not so easy to answer, writes Glen Scanlon.
